childhood_context.html:
Childhood: {{BIRTH_YEAR}}-{{CHILDHOOD_END_YEAR}}

You were born the year YouTube was founded and Hurricane Katrina drowned New Orleans. Pope John Paul II died after 26 years, and the world watched on a brand-new platform called Google Video. Your birth year was a pivot point—the last gasp of a pre-smartphone world that would vanish before you started kindergarten.

Your childhood didn't just overlap with the smartphone revolution—it was defined by it. The iPhone arrived when you were two. The iPad dropped when you were five. You weren't learning to use tablets; you were learning to talk while swiping. Your parents recorded your first steps on a device that hadn't existed when they were your age. You were the beta testers for a digital childhood nobody had planned.

You were three during the 2008 financial crisis. You don't remember it, but you lived it. Maybe your family moved. Maybe a parent lost a job. Maybe the tension in the house was sharper than it should have been. The recession was the background radiation of your early years, even if you couldn't name it.

Your childhood TV was streaming from the start. Netflix mailed DVDs when you were born, but by the time you could work a remote, it was instant. You grew up thinking buffering was the worst thing that could happen to a person. You never knew the agony of missing a show because you weren't home when it aired. Your relationship with media was always on-demand.

You were ten when the Boston Marathon bombing happened. Twelve when ISIS beheaded journalists on video. Thirteen when Pulse nightclub was attacked. Your childhood wasn't innocent—it was punctuated by notifications, breaking news alerts, and the slow realization that nowhere was actually safe. You learned to process tragedy in real-time, on screens, surrounded by adults who were equally overwhelmed.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Generation Z, born between 1997 and 2012. The name is placeholder that stuck—the generation after Millennials, the last letter of the alphabet, which feels appropriate for a cohort that sometimes talks like they're the last of everything. Your generation is about 68 million people in the US, slightly smaller than Millennials but significantly louder online.

Gen Z's defining moment is less a single event and more a mood: ambient dread. You don't remember 9/11. You barely remember the Obama years. Your political consciousness formed during Trump, COVID, climate protests, and mass shootings that happened so regularly they stopped making national news. Your generation grew up with crisis as the default setting.

You're digital natives in a way Millennials only thought they were. Millennials adapted to smartphones. You never knew life without them. You learned to read partly from YouTube. You learned social dynamics from group chats. You learned about the world from algorithms that prioritized engagement over accuracy.

Your generation is stereotyped as anxious, ironic, and chronically online—and you'd probably agree with all three. You cope through humor, specifically the kind of surrealist, self-deprecating humor that makes older generations uncomfortable. You've normalized talking about mental health because pretending everything was fine clearly wasn't working for anyone.

You're more ethnically diverse than any previous American generation. You're more likely to identify as LGBTQ+. You're less religious, less partisan, and less trusting of institutions. You've watched every system your parents believed in fail in real-time. Your skepticism isn't cynicism—it's pattern recognition.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Batman Begins rebooted superhero movies and Revenge of the Sith closed out the Star Wars prequels that your older siblings actually watched in theaters. Crash won Best Picture, which nobody remembers fondly. Coldplay's 'Fix You' became the song that would soundtrack every emotional montage for the next twenty years.

Your childhood was Disney Channel original movies, iCarly, and Phineas and Ferb. You probably had opinions about whether Wizards of Waverly Place was better than Hannah Montana. You learned what drama meant from preteen sitcoms where nobody's parents were ever home. Nickelodeon and Disney were fighting for your attention, and you gave it freely.

By middle school, Minecraft was your entire personality. YouTube was your television. PewDiePie was more famous than most movie stars. You watched people play video games instead of playing them yourself, which older generations found baffling but which made perfect sense to you. Why play when you could watch someone better while eating lunch?

High school was TikTok, which launched globally the year you turned thirteen. The app rewired your attention span, your humor, and your sense of what counted as famous. You could become a celebrity in 60 seconds or less. You could watch your favorite creator fall from grace in the same timeframe. The parasocial relationships were intense and disposable.

Your music taste was algorithm-formed. Spotify told you what to like. The concept of buying an album seemed quaint. You probably have strong opinions about Taylor Swift, whether positive or negative, because she dominated your entire adolescence. You experienced Billie Eilish as zeitgeist rather than discovery. Your relationship with pop culture is mediated, curated, and endlessly recommended.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe was your mythology. You saw Avengers: Endgame in theaters at fourteen, which felt like the cultural event of a lifetime—until it didn't matter anymore because everything became content and nothing stayed special for long.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year YouTube launched. Google had only been public for one year. Facebook was still limited to college students. The technology that would define your generation either didn't exist yet or hadn't escaped the dorms.

The iPhone arrived when you were two. By the time you were forming memories, touchscreens were normal. You didn't adapt to smartphones—you emerged from the womb reaching for one. Your parents probably have embarrassing videos of you, barely verbal, navigating an iPad with the fluency of a systems engineer.

You were seven when Instagram launched. Nine when Snapchat appeared. Thirteen when TikTok went global. Your social development happened alongside the evolution of social media. Each platform shaped a different era of your personality. You've left digital fossils across half a dozen apps, most of which you now find mortifying.

You've never used a phone book. Never gotten directions from a map. Never waited for film to be developed. The analog world existed, technically, but you've only encountered it as aesthetic—vinyl records, instant cameras, the deliberate choice to be retro.

Your generation treats technology like oxygen—essential and invisible until it's gone. Wi-Fi outages feel like emergencies. Phone batteries dying trigger genuine anxiety. You've never been unreachable, which sounds like freedom but often feels like a leash.

You're the first generation to have your entire childhood documented online without your consent. Baby photos on Facebook before you could consent to being photographed. First day of school posts that will outlive everyone who cared. Your digital footprint started before you could walk, and you'll spend adulthood trying to manage it.

AI became mainstream during your adolescence. ChatGPT launched when you were seventeen. By the time you hit the workforce, you'll be competing with, collaborating with, or being replaced by systems that didn't exist when you started high school. Your relationship with technology isn't nostalgia for what's lost—it's anxiety about what's coming.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when Hurricane Katrina made landfall. Over 1,800 people died. New Orleans drowned on live television while the federal government fumbled. You don't remember it, but it was the preview for a century of climate disasters that would feel increasingly normal.

You were three during the 2008 financial crisis. The adults were terrified. The economy collapsed. Houses became worthless. Jobs evaporated. You absorbed the anxiety without understanding the cause. Your relationship with economic security was shaped by a crisis you were too young to name but old enough to feel.

You were six when Obama was inaugurated. Black president. Historic moment. Hope and change as a brand. You were too young to vote but old enough to absorb the optimism that older people felt. You were also there when that optimism curdled into something else.

You were eight when Bin Laden was killed. You'd grown up with the War on Terror as background noise, never knowing a country not at war, not understanding why everyone was so relieved about a name you'd only heard as a boogeyman.

You were ten when Sandy Hook happened. Twenty children your age, dead in their classrooms. You'd already had lockdown drills. Now you understood why. Your generation is the one that grew up expecting school shootings, treating active shooter training like fire drills—annoying but necessary, probably won't happen to you specifically.

You were eleven when Trump descended the escalator. Fifteen when COVID hit. Your sophomore year of high school disappeared into Zoom calls and isolation. You missed proms, graduations, first kisses, all the stupid teenage milestones that are supposed to happen. You came out the other side different, and nobody's quite sure how.

You were seventeen when Russia invaded Ukraine. Eighteen when inflation ate everyone's savings. You've watched democracy fracture, climate records shatter, and institutions fail at a pace that makes history feel less like a subject and more like a series of push notifications.

By twenty, you've lived through a pandemic, an insurrection, multiple once-in-a-generation economic crises, and weather events that used to be rare. You're not traumatized by any single event. You're traumatized by the accumulation.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You'll enter the workforce around {{CAREER_START_YEAR}}, assuming you follow a traditional path—which you probably won't, because traditional paths collapsed before you could take them. College costs more than a house used to. Trade school is getting recommended more often. The gig economy is waiting with open arms and no benefits.

Your generation watched Millennials graduate into the 2008 crisis and took notes. You're not expecting the job market to work for you. You're expecting to make it work, somehow, through side hustles, content creation, multiple income streams, or sheer force of will.

Remote work isn't a perk to you—it's an expectation. COVID proved offices were optional. You did high school from your bedroom. Why would work be different? You'll confuse employers who think presence equals productivity, and you'll frustrate managers who learned leadership by watching people work in person.

Your career expectations are simultaneously lower and higher than previous generations. Lower because you don't expect loyalty, stability, or a pension. Higher because you actually expect your work to mean something. You want purpose. You want flexibility. You want your employer's values to align with yours. This makes you annoying to hire and expensive to keep.

You'll change jobs constantly, not because you're flaky but because loyalty gets you nowhere. The median job tenure for your generation will be measured in months, not years. Companies that want to keep you will need to actually try. Most won't bother.

You're entering a workforce being reshaped by AI. The skills you learned might be obsolete before you use them. The jobs you're training for might not exist. The anxiety isn't theoretical—it's watching chatbots write code while you're still paying off a computer science degree.

Your saving grace is adaptability. You've never expected stability. You've always assumed the ground would shift. That makes you resilient in ways older workers aren't. You'll figure it out because figuring it out is all you've ever known.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Your first relationships probably happened on apps. Not dating apps necessarily—just apps. Instagram DMs, Snapchat streaks, Discord servers, TikTok duets that turned into something more. The line between online and offline relationships blurred before you knew there was supposed to be a line.

You've never cold-called a crush. The idea of asking someone out in person, without testing the waters via social media first, sounds insane. Why risk rejection when you can analyze their digital presence, gauge interest through likes, and make your move with plausible deniability?

Your communication style is asynchronous by default. You text instead of call. You leave voice memos instead of having conversations. You're available constantly but rarely in real-time. This makes deep connection harder and surface connection easier. You have more friends than any generation before, spread across more platforms, with less actual intimacy.

You're delaying everything your parents did early. Dating, sex, relationships, marriage—all pushed later than previous generations. Some of this is choice: you're pickier, less willing to settle, more comfortable being alone. Some is economic: you can't afford to date when you can't afford rent.

Your generation is lonelier than any before, by the numbers. More time online correlates with less time with people. The pandemic accelerated isolation that was already building. You know how to be alone. You're less sure how to be together.

But you're also more emotionally literate than previous generations. You have language for attachment styles, boundaries, emotional labor. You go to therapy without stigma. You communicate needs with vocabulary your parents never learned. The relationships you do build might be less frequent but more intentional.

You'll probably have fewer partners, marry later (if at all), and have kids even later (if at all). The life script is optional now. You're making it up as you go, which is terrifying and also kind of freeing.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were three during the Great Recession. Fifteen during the COVID crash. Twenty during whatever's happening right now. Your financial consciousness formed in an economy that has never, in your memory, been stable. The baseline is uncertainty. The expectation is crisis.

Your relationship with money is defined by watching your parents struggle. Maybe they lost a house. Maybe they couldn't afford the things their parents could. You absorbed their anxiety before you understood compound interest. Money, to you, is less about accumulation and more about survival.

You've never expected to own a home. The math doesn't work. Houses cost ten times what they cost when your grandparents bought theirs. Wages haven't kept pace. Student loans consume whatever's left. The American Dream of homeownership is something you learned about in history class, not something you're planning for.

You're financially conservative in unexpected ways. You research purchases obsessively. You're suspicious of debt. You save compulsively when you can, spend chaotically when you can't. The YOLO spending on experiences makes sense when you assume the future is uncertain anyway.

Crypto and meme stocks appealed to your generation for a reason: the traditional path to wealth is blocked. If the game is rigged, why not gamble? If working hard doesn't guarantee success, why not YOLO into something that might go to the moon? Your financial risk tolerance is either zero or infinite, with nothing in between.

You'll inherit less than any generation before. Your parents, if they're Millennials or late Gen X, don't have wealth to pass down. They're still paying off student loans, still renting, still figuring it out. The generational wealth transfer everyone talks about will skip right over you.

But you're also less attached to the markers of success that trapped previous generations. You don't need a big house to feel successful. You don't need a fancy car. You measure wealth in flexibility, experiences, freedom from the anxiety you watched your parents live with. Your relationship with money is broken, but at least you know it.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's greatest strength is also your weakness: you've never known stability, so you don't expect it. This makes you resilient but also resigned. You adapt to dysfunction instead of demanding better. You cope instead of organizing. The hustle culture you mock online is the same hustle culture you practice in private.

You're so fluent in irony that sincerity feels dangerous. Caring about something earnestly opens you to mockery. So you hedge everything with humor, distance, detachment. This protects you but also prevents you from committing fully to anything—causes, relationships, careers. Everything gets the same ironic treatment, even things that deserve passion.

Your attention span has been optimized for dopamine hits. You know this. You can articulate exactly how TikTok rewired your brain. But knowing and fixing are different things. Long-form content feels like work. Boredom triggers phone checking. Your ability to focus on anything for extended periods has been genuinely damaged, and you'll spend decades trying to repair it.

You're so good at identifying problems that you sometimes forget to build solutions. Critique is your native language. You can deconstruct any system, expose any hypocrisy, identify every flaw. But criticism is easier than creation. Your generation points out what's broken better than any before. Building what comes next is harder.

Your online fluency created offline deficits. Small talk feels awkward. Eye contact is harder than it should be. Phone calls trigger anxiety. The social skills that previous generations absorbed from constant in-person interaction—you didn't get those hours. You're playing catch-up on skills your parents didn't realize they were teaching you by taking you places where phones didn't exist.

You assume everyone is performing. Because you are. Because everyone online is. But this bleeds into offline life, making it hard to trust that anyone means what they say. Authenticity, when you encounter it, feels suspicious. Your default mode is skeptical, which protects you but also prevents genuine connection.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s ({{TWENTIES_START}}-{{TWENTIES_END}}): You're in this decade now, or just entering it. The job market is chaos. Housing is unaffordable. The economy does something inexplicable every six months. You're not building a career—you're surviving one crisis at a time while trying to figure out what you actually want. Your twenties will be defined by adaptation, experimentation, and the slow realization that nobody else knows what they're doing either. Don't expect stability. Build skills instead of positions. Your career will be a portfolio, not a ladder.

Your 30s ({{THIRTIES_START}}-{{THIRTIES_END}}): By now, the chaos might have a shape. You'll have figured out what you're good at, what you can tolerate, what you actually want. The pressure to have it together will increase. Marriage? Kids? Career? Everyone will have opinions. Your job is to ignore most of them. This is the decade where you'll either make peace with the instability you've always known or exhaust yourself trying to build the stability your parents couldn't. The smart move is somewhere in between.

Your 40s ({{FORTIES_START}}-{{FORTIES_END}}): You'll be managing people who think they invented remote work. You'll be explaining to interns what life was like before AI did half their job. You'll be peak earning, probably, but also peak responsibility. Parents aging, maybe kids growing, definitely careers demanding. The work-life balance will feel more urgent because you'll finally have a life worth balancing. Climate change will be undeniably shaping where you can live. The skills you built for crisis will serve you well.

Your 50s ({{FIFTIES_START}}-{{FIFTIES_END}}): The generation after you will be entering the workforce, and they'll make you feel old in ways you didn't expect. You'll be the elder statesperson of whatever industry you're in, assuming industries still exist in recognizable forms. Retirement will be a concept you start thinking about without expecting it to happen traditionally. Your kids, if you have them, will be becoming adults. Your parents might need care. You'll be sandwiched, stretched, but hopefully more at peace with uncertainty than you were at twenty.

Your 60s and beyond ({{SIXTIES_START}}+): The world will be unrecognizable from the one you grew up in. Climate migration will have reshaped geography. AI will have reshaped work. Social media will have evolved into something you can't predict. You'll be the last generation that remembers the pre-smartphone world, even if you don't remember it well. Younger people will ask what it was like. You'll tell them about TikTok and COVID and they'll nod like you're describing ancient history. Because you will be.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.1 million people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. The entire Gen Z generation is about 68 million people in the US, slightly smaller than Millennials but growing into adulthood with very different expectations and experiences.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more diverse, more skeptical, and you entered digital life even earlier. Millennials remember dial-up. You've always had broadband. Millennials adopted smartphones. You were raised by them. They graduated into the Great Recession. You grew up in its aftermath. You share the same economic anxieties but different reference points.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're practically aliens to each other. They grew up with latchkey independence and analog boredom. You grew up monitored, connected, and endlessly entertained. They think you're fragile. You think they're weirdly proud of neglect. Neither is entirely wrong.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the chasm is unbridgeable. They bought houses for a year's salary. You'll be lucky to buy one at all. They had pensions. You have anxiety. They think you're entitled. You think they broke everything and blamed you for the mess. Thanksgiving dinner remains tense.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), you're the last generation that remembers any world before total digital immersion. Gen Alpha won't have your transitional memories. They won't remember a time before tablets. You're the bridge between analog-adjacent Millennials and fully digital Gen Alpha. That perspective—knowing both worlds—might be your greatest generational asset.

Your life expectancy is projected around 77-79 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising deaths of despair, climate-related health impacts, and healthcare costs that make prevention a luxury. Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, but you're also more likely to seek treatment. You're more medicated, more therapized, and more willing to talk about it.

You're the most educated generation in history entering the worst economic conditions for young people in decades. You're more tolerant, more inclusive, and more skeptical of institutions than any generation before. You didn't break the world. You inherited it broken. What you build from here is the question.

year_events: Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast
